text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm wid warm calamari salad that's
right as the great chef Mick Jaggar once
said you can't always get what you want
but if you try a recipe like this
sometimes you get what you need except I
didn't want what I needed I wanted what
I wanted which was a beautifully seared
calamari salad but as you'll see that
didn't quite happen so while things did
not go exactly as planned
let me show you this anyway because I
still think there's a couple valuable
things you'll pick up so let's go ahead
and get started and first up we have to
prep our calamari so I have one pound
that's been fully cleaned and ready to
cook of course you're going to have the
mixture between your tubes and your
tentacles and by the way this is often
referred to as simply squid or baby
squid or the hip hop name which is
little Kraken but anyway like I said I
have a pound which we're going to need
to cut out before we cook it so for the
body section or the tubes as they're
called we're simply going to cut across
like this into rings not too small at
least a quarter inch and then as far as
the tentacle sections if they're small
you can just leave them whole but I
generally like to cut the bigger ones in
half and then maybe we'll also separate
that long piece I have no idea what that
is but I do know it's edible and once
our calamari is cut up we're going to
toss that in a bowl where we will add
all our seasonings right now this stuff
cooks so fast there's actually no time
to add it to the pan so we'll transfer
that into a bowl and we'll start with a
little bit of vegetable oil followed by
not one but three kinds of dried pepper
I'm going to do some Aleppo chili flakes
you could certainly do just regular red
chili flakes I'm also going to do some
Chipotle which is nothing more than a
smoked dried jalapeno and then lastly
just we would surprise no one will do a
little pinch of cayenne and then to
balance the heat we need a little bit of
sweet so I'm going to put in about a
teaspoon of brown sugar and then because
I had one I also decide to add 1 sliced
jalapeno I just cut it in rings so it
would be geometrically correct with the
calamari and by the way I did knock out
most of the seeds and then other than a
big pinch of salt that is pretty much it
for our seasonings so I mix that up with
my freakishly small wooden spoon and
once that was mixed up thoroughly I set
it aside so we could prep the other main
component of this salad the salad in a
bowl I'm going to put a couple handfuls
of baby arugula along with some already
cooked white beans which have been
thoroughly rinsed and drained
and to that we'll add some freshly
ground black pepper and a pinch of salt
and then as far as addressing goes I'm
going to go very simple and just use
some olive oil and freshly squeezed
lemon juice and what I really wanted
this recipe to be was a cold bitter
green and white bean salad topped with
hot seared hopefully charred calamari
but as you're about to see only half of
that plan worked out so we'll dress our
salad and then we'll get in there with
our big hairy paws and give it a good
mixing and once that was said I divided
myself between my two bowls at which
point it was time to sear /hr my
calamari and of course the only way to
do that is in a super super super hot
pan so I took my biggest heaviest
cast-iron skillet I put it on high heat
for a long time until it was literally
smoking and I was a little nervous
because we had added a little bit of
sugar I was kind of afraid it would over
char but as you'll see that didn't
happen so I added my calamari in and I
figured I would let it sit for about a
minute just like that and then kind of
stir-fry it for another minute and it
would be done if you haven't worked with
it before calamari cooks super fast like
literally in two minutes but it was
right here after that first minute when
I started to stir then I realized this
is not working I mean it was cooking
fine but there was absolutely no color
no sear no char no caramelized goodness
so what happened is I just had too much
product which cooled down the pan too
much which prevented any serious serine
or charring but like I said calamari
cooked so fast there's no time to stop
to be sad so I just kept stirring for
another few seconds and as soon as those
rings basically turn from something that
looks raw and translucent to something
that looks white and cooked you have to
stop and serve immediately which is what
I did so I quickly spoon that over my
arugula and white beans knowing full
well that it would wilt slightly that
was part of the plan and of course I'm
going to remind you again always wipe
the edges of your plates you can't serve
someone with a big splatter on the edge
of the bowl come on and then for some
final touches I did a little bit of
olive oil and a little more pepper and
last but not least a little bit of fresh
lemon and my warm calamari salad was
done and there really wasn't anything
wrong with this plate of food per se
except it wasn't what I initially
envisioned so my brain and eyes just
wouldn't let me enjoy this on its own
merits since like I said I really wanted
something severely
seared and charred something much closer
to like a grilled calamari so that was
the problem here but even though the
squid did not char because we only cook
it for a couple minutes it still was
very nice very sweet very moist very
tender and it really did go nicely with
the white beans in the wilted arugula
but like I said that didn't matter
because it was not what I wanted I mean
I love a good peanut butter and jelly
sandwich but if you bring me one after I
order a cheeseburger we're gonna have
words but anyway the bottom line it's
still made for pretty nice lunch and
with that we will conclude the latest
episode of Chef John's culinary
self-flagellation every once in a while
the food gods throws a surprise you know
to humble us a little like we need it
but I still hope you give some variation
of this a try so head over to food
wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
